original_data.question: A 3-month-old girl is brought to a pediatrician by her parents. She has central cyanosis without signs of respiratory distress or signs of heart failure. An echocardiogram reveals severe pulmonary outflow obstruction, right ventricular hypertrophy, a ventricular septal defect, and an overriding of the aorta. An elective primary surgical repair is planned at 4 months of age. Which of the following statements is true about this girl’s condition?

options.A: The tricuspid valve is the most common valve affected by bacterial endocarditis in uncorrected tetralogy of Fallot.
options.B: Normal hemoglobin in patients with tetralogy of Fallot does not rule out iron deficiency anemia.
options.C: Cerebral arterial thrombosis is more common than cerebral venous thrombosis.
options.D: Refractory heart failure is a common complication of tetralogy of Fallot.

model_response:
This girl’s condition is tetralogy of Fallot. The four components of tetralogy of Fallot are ventricular septal defect, pulmonary outflow obstruction, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy. The tricuspid valve is not affected in tetralogy of Fallot. Normal hemoglobin does not rule out iron deficiency anemia. Cerebral arterial thrombosis is more common than cerebral venous thrombosis in patients with cyanotic congenital heart disease. Refractory heart failure is not a common complication of tetralogy of Fallot.

Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
A medical doctor with specialized training in the care of children.
Persons functioning as natural, adoptive, or substitute parents. The heading includes the concept of parenthood as well as preparation for becoming a parent.
A form of cyanosis that occurs when there is a decrease in oxygen saturation in the arterial blood, usually with an SaO2 of below 75%.
A pathological increase in the effort and frequency of breathing movements.
A group or system of signs, used to show information about something.

Inability of the heart to pump blood at an adequate rate to meet tissue metabolic requirements. Clinical symptoms of heart failure include: unusual dyspnea on light exertion, recurrent dyspnea occurring in the supine position, fluid retention or rales, jugular venous distension, pulmonary edema on physical exam, or pulmonary edema on chest x-ray presumed to be cardiac dysfunction.
Ultrasonic recording of the size, motion, and composition of the heart and surrounding tissues. The standard approach is transthoracic.
Any hindrance to the passage of air into and out of the lungs.
Enlargement of the RIGHT VENTRICLE of the heart. This increase in ventricular mass is often attributed to PULMONARY HYPERTENSION and is a contributor to cardiovascular morbidity and mortality.

Developmental abnormalities in any portion of the VENTRICULAR SEPTUM resulting in abnormal communications between the two lower chambers of the heart. Classification of ventricular septal defects is based on location of the communication, such as perimembranous, inlet, outlet (infundibular), central muscular, marginal muscular, or apical muscular defect.
The main trunk of the systemic arteries.
Restoring, to the extent possible, the natural anatomical structure.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
How long something has existed; elapsed time since birth.
A verbal and/or written message that asserts, affirms, or declares something.
A state of being, such as a state of health.
